summary.long: 2 Samuel is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: After the death of Saul, David returned from his victory over the Amalekites and spent two days in Ziklag.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the third day a man arrived from Saul’s army camp. He had torn his clothes and put dirt on his head to show that he was in mourning. He fell to the ground before David in deep respect.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Where have you come from?” David asked.
“I escaped from the Israelite camp,” the man replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“What happened?” David demanded. “Tell me how the battle went.”
The man replied, “Our entire army fled from the battle. Many of the men are dead, and Saul and his son Jonathan are also dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “How do you know Saul and Jonathan are dead?” David demanded of the young man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man answered, “I happened to be on Mount Gilboa, and there was Saul leaning on his spear with the enemy chariots and charioteers closing in on him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he turned and saw me, he cried out for me to come to him. ‘How can I help?’ I asked him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“He responded, ‘Who are you?’
“‘I am an Amalekite,’ I told him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then he begged me, ‘Come over here and put me out of my misery, for I am in terrible pain and want to die.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “So I killed him,” the Amalekite told David, “for I knew he couldn’t live. Then I took his crown and his armband, and I have brought them here to you, my lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David and his men tore their clothes in sorrow when they heard the news.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They mourned and wept and fasted all day for Saul and his son Jonathan, and for the Lord’s army and the nation of Israel, because they had died by the sword that day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then David said to the young man who had brought the news, “Where are you from?”
And he replied, “I am a foreigner, an Amalekite, who lives in your land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Why were you not afraid to kill the Lord’s anointed one?” David asked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to one of his men, “Kill him!” So the man thrust his sword into the Amalekite and killed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You have condemned yourself,” David said, “for you yourself confessed that you killed the Lord’s anointed one.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David composed a funeral song for Saul and Jonathan,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he commanded that it be taught to the people of Judah. It is known as the Song of the Bow, and it is recorded in The Book of Jashar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your pride and joy, O Israel, lies dead on the hills!
    Oh, how the mighty heroes have fallen!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Don’t announce the news in Gath,
    don’t proclaim it in the streets of Ashkelon,
or the daughters of the Philistines will rejoice
    and the pagans will laugh in triumph.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
The bow of Jonathan was powerful,
    and the sword of Saul did its mighty work.
They shed the blood of their enemies
    and pierced the bodies of mighty heroes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How beloved and gracious were Saul and Jonathan!
    They were together in life and in death.
They were swifter than eagles,
    stronger than lions.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Oh, how the mighty heroes have fallen in battle!
    Jonathan lies dead on the hills.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How I weep for you, my brother Jonathan!
    Oh, how much I loved you!
And your love for me was deep,
    deeper than the love of women!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Oh, how the mighty heroes have fallen!
    Stripped of their weapons, they lie dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
After this, David asked the Lord, “Should I move back to one of the towns of Judah?”
“Yes,” the Lord replied.
Then David asked, “Which town should I go to?”
“To Hebron,” the Lord answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David’s two wives were Ahinoam from Jezreel and Abigail, the widow of Nabal from Carmel. So David and his wives
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and his men and their families all moved to Judah, and they settled in the villages near Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the men of Judah came to David and anointed him king over the people of Judah.
When David heard that the men of Jabesh-gilead had buried Saul,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he sent them this message: “May the Lord bless you for being so loyal to your master Saul and giving him a decent burial.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May the Lord be loyal to you in return and reward you with his unfailing love! And I, too, will reward you for what you have done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now that Saul is dead, I ask you to be my strong and loyal subjects like the people of Judah, who have anointed me as their new king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Abner son of Ner, the commander of Saul’s army, had already gone to Mahanaim with Saul’s son Ishbosheth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There he proclaimed Ishbosheth king over Gilead, Jezreel, Ephraim, Benjamin, the land of the Ashurites, and all the rest of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishbosheth, Saul’s son, was forty years old when he became king, and he ruled from Mahanaim for two years. Meanwhile, the people of Judah remained loyal to David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David made Hebron his capital, and he ruled as king of Judah for seven and a half years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day Abner led Ishbosheth’s troops from Mahanaim to Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: About the same time, Joab son of Zeruiah led David’s troops out and met them at the pool of Gibeon. The two groups sat down there, facing each other from opposite sides of the pool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Abner suggested to Joab, “Let’s have a few of our warriors fight hand to hand here in front of us.”
“All right,” Joab agreed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So twelve men were chosen to fight from each side—twelve men of Benjamin representing Ishbosheth son of Saul, and twelve representing David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each one grabbed his opponent by the hair and thrust his sword into the other’s side so that all of them died. So this place at Gibeon has been known ever since as the Field of Swords.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A fierce battle followed that day, and Abner and the men of Israel were defeated by the forces of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab, Abishai, and Asahel—the three sons of Zeruiah—were among David’s forces that day. Asahel could run like a gazelle,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he began chasing Abner. He pursued him relentlessly, not stopping for anything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When Abner looked back and saw him coming, he called out, “Is that you, Asahel?”
“Yes, it is,” he replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go fight someone else!” Abner warned. “Take on one of the younger men, and strip him of his weapons.” But Asahel kept right on chasing Abner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Again Abner shouted to him, “Get away from here! I don’t want to kill you. How could I ever face your brother Joab again?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Asahel refused to turn back, so Abner thrust the butt end of his spear through Asahel’s stomach, and the spear came out through his back. He stumbled to the ground and died there. And everyone who came by that spot stopped and stood still when they saw Asahel lying there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joab and Abishai found out what had happened, they set out after Abner. The sun was just going down as they arrived at the hill of Ammah near Giah, along the road to the wilderness of Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner’s troops from the tribe of Benjamin regrouped there at the top of the hill to take a stand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner shouted down to Joab, “Must we always be killing each other? Don’t you realize that bitterness is the only result? When will you call off your men from chasing their Israelite brothers?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab said, “God only knows what would have happened if you hadn’t spoken, for we would have chased you all night if necessary.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab blew the ram’s horn, and his men stopped chasing the troops of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All that night Abner and his men retreated through the Jordan Valley. They crossed the Jordan River, traveling all through the morning, and didn’t stop until they arrived at Mahanaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, Joab and his men also returned home. When Joab counted his casualties, he discovered that only 19 men were missing in addition to Asahel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But 360 of Abner’s men had been killed, all from the tribe of Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab and his men took Asahel’s body to Bethlehem and buried him there in his father’s tomb. Then they traveled all night and reached Hebron at daybreak.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That was the beginning of a long war between those who were loyal to Saul and those loyal to David. As time passed David became stronger and stronger, while Saul’s dynasty became weaker and weaker.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These are the sons who were born to David in Hebron:
The oldest was Amnon, whose mother was Ahinoam from Jezreel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The second was Daniel, whose mother was Abigail, the widow of Nabal from Carmel.
The third was Absalom, whose mother was Maacah, the daughter of Talmai, king of Geshur.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The fourth was Adonijah, whose mother was Haggith.
The fifth was Shephatiah, whose mother was Abital.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sixth was Ithream, whose mother was Eglah, David’s wife.
These sons were all born to David in Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the war between the house of Saul and the house of David went on, Abner became a powerful leader among those loyal to Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day Ishbosheth, Saul’s son, accused Abner of sleeping with one of his father’s concubines, a woman named Rizpah, daughter of Aiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner was furious. “Am I some Judean dog to be kicked around like this?” he shouted. “After all I have done for your father, Saul, and his family and friends by not handing you over to David, is this my reward—that you find fault with me about this woman?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May God strike me and even kill me if I don’t do everything I can to help David get what the Lord has promised him!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’m going to take Saul’s kingdom and give it to David. I will establish the throne of David over Israel as well as Judah, all the way from Dan in the north to Beersheba in the south.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishbosheth didn’t dare say another word because he was afraid of what Abner might do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abner sent messengers to David, saying, “Doesn’t the entire land belong to you? Make a solemn pact with me, and I will help turn over all of Israel to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “All right,” David replied, “but I will not negotiate with you unless you bring back my wife Michal, Saul’s daughter, when you come.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David then sent this message to Ishbosheth, Saul’s son: “Give me back my wife Michal, for I bought her with the lives of 100 Philistines.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ishbosheth took Michal away from her husband, Palti son of Laish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Palti followed along behind her as far as Bahurim, weeping as he went. Then Abner told him, “Go back home!” So Palti returned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, Abner had consulted with the elders of Israel. “For some time now,” he told them, “you have wanted to make David your king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now is the time! For the Lord has said, ‘I have chosen David to save my people Israel from the hands of the Philistines and from all their other enemies.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner also spoke with the men of Benjamin. Then he went to Hebron to tell David that all the people of Israel and Benjamin had agreed to support him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Abner and twenty of his men came to Hebron, David entertained them with a great feast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abner said to David, “Let me go and call an assembly of all Israel to support my lord the king. They will make a covenant with you to make you their king, and you will rule over everything your heart desires.” So David sent Abner safely on his way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But just after David had sent Abner away in safety, Joab and some of David’s troops returned from a raid, bringing much plunder with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joab arrived, he was told that Abner had just been there visiting the king and had been sent away in safety.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab rushed to the king and demanded, “What have you done? What do you mean by letting Abner get away?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You know perfectly well that he came to spy on you and find out everything you’re doing!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab then left David and sent messengers to catch up with Abner, asking him to return. They found him at the well of Sirah and brought him back, though David knew nothing about it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Abner arrived back at Hebron, Joab took him aside at the gateway as if to speak with him privately. But then he stabbed Abner in the stomach and killed him in revenge for killing his brother Asahel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David heard about it, he declared, “I vow by the Lord that I and my kingdom are forever innocent of this crime against Abner son of Ner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab and his family are the guilty ones. May the family of Joab be cursed in every generation with a man who has open sores or leprosy or who walks on crutches or dies by the sword or begs for food!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab and his brother Abishai killed Abner because Abner had killed their brother Asahel at the battle of Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to Joab and all those who were with him, “Tear your clothes and put on burlap. Mourn for Abner.” And King David himself walked behind the procession to the grave.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They buried Abner in Hebron, and the king and all the people wept at his graveside.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the king sang this funeral song for Abner:
“Should Abner have died as fools die?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your hands were not bound;
    your feet were not chained.
No, you were murdered—
    the victim of a wicked plot.”
All the people wept again for Abner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David had refused to eat anything on the day of the funeral, and now everyone begged him to eat. But David had made a vow, saying, “May God strike me and even kill me if I eat anything before sundown.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This pleased the people very much. In fact, everything the king did pleased them!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So everyone in Judah and all Israel understood that David was not responsible for Abner’s murder.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King David said to his officials, “Don’t you realize that a great commander has fallen today in Israel?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And even though I am the anointed king, these two sons of Zeruiah—Joab and Abishai—are too strong for me to control. So may the Lord repay these evil men for their evil deeds.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ishbosheth, Saul’s son, heard about Abner’s death at Hebron, he lost all courage, and all Israel became paralyzed with fear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now there were two brothers, Baanah and Recab, who were captains of Ishbosheth’s raiding parties. They were sons of Rimmon, a member of the tribe of Benjamin who lived in Beeroth. The town of Beeroth is now part of Benjamin’s territory
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because the original people of Beeroth fled to Gittaim, where they still live as foreigners.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Saul’s son Jonathan had a son named Mephibosheth, who was crippled as a child. He was five years old when the report came from Jezreel that Saul and Jonathan had been killed in battle. When the child’s nurse heard the news, she picked him up and fled. But as she hurried away, she dropped him, and he became crippled.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day Recab and Baanah, the sons of Rimmon from Beeroth, went to Ishbosheth’s house around noon as he was taking his midday rest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The doorkeeper, who had been sifting wheat, became drowsy and fell asleep. So Recab and Baanah slipped past her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They went into the house and found Ishbosheth sleeping on his bed. They struck and killed him and cut off his head. Then, taking his head with them, they fled across the Jordan Valley through the night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they arrived at Hebron, they presented Ishbosheth’s head to David. “Look!” they exclaimed to the king. “Here is the head of Ishbosheth, the son of your enemy Saul who tried to kill you. Today the Lord has given my lord the king revenge on Saul and his entire family!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But David said to Recab and Baanah, “The Lord, who saves me from all my enemies, is my witness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Someone once told me, ‘Saul is dead,’ thinking he was bringing me good news. But I seized him and killed him at Ziklag. That’s the reward I gave him for his news!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How much more should I reward evil men who have killed an innocent man in his own house and on his own bed? Shouldn’t I hold you responsible for his blood and rid the earth of you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David ordered his young men to kill them, and they did. They cut off their hands and feet and hung their bodies beside the pool in Hebron. Then they took Ishbosheth’s head and buried it in Abner’s tomb in Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the tribes of Israel went to David at Hebron and told him, “We are your own flesh and blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the past, when Saul was our king, you were the one who really led the forces of Israel. And the Lord told you, ‘You will be the shepherd of my people Israel. You will be Israel’s leader.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So there at Hebron, King David made a covenant before the Lord with all the elders of Israel. And they anointed him king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was thirty years old when he began to reign, and he reigned forty years in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had reigned over Judah from Hebron for seven years and six months, and from Jerusalem he reigned over all Israel and Judah for thirty-three years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David then led his men to Jerusalem to fight against the Jebusites, the original inhabitants of the land who were living there. The Jebusites taunted David, saying, “You’ll never get in here! Even the blind and lame could keep you out!” For the Jebusites thought they were safe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But David captured the fortress of Zion, which is now called the City of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the day of the attack, David said to his troops, “I hate those ‘lame’ and ‘blind’ Jebusites. Whoever attacks them should strike by going into the city through the water tunnel.” That is the origin of the saying, “The blind and the lame may not enter the house.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David made the fortress his home, and he called it the City of David. He extended the city, starting at the supporting terraces and working inward.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And David became more and more powerful, because the Lord God of Heaven’s Armies was with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Hiram of Tyre sent messengers to David, along with cedar timber and carpenters and stonemasons, and they built David a palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And David realized that the Lord had confirmed him as king over Israel and had blessed his kingdom for the sake of his people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After moving from Hebron to Jerusalem, David married more concubines and wives, and they had more sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the names of David’s sons who were born in Jerusalem: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ibhar, Elishua, Nepheg, Japhia,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Philistines heard that David had been anointed king of Israel, they mobilized all their forces to capture him. But David was told they were coming, so he went into the stronghold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines arrived and spread out across the valley of Rephaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So David asked the Lord, “Should I go out to fight the Philistines? Will you hand them over to me?”
The Lord replied to David, “Yes, go ahead. I will certainly hand them over to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David went to Baal-perazim and defeated the Philistines there. “The Lord did it!” David exclaimed. “He burst through my enemies like a raging flood!” So he named that place Baal-perazim (which means “the Lord who bursts through”).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines had abandoned their idols there, so David and his men confiscated them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But after a while the Philistines returned and again spread out across the valley of Rephaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And again David asked the Lord what to do. “Do not attack them straight on,” the Lord replied. “Instead, circle around behind and attack them near the poplar trees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you hear a sound like marching feet in the tops of the poplar trees, be on the alert! That will be the signal that the Lord is moving ahead of you to strike down the Philistine army.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David did what the Lord commanded, and he struck down the Philistines all the way from Gibeon to Gezer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David again gathered all the elite troops in Israel, 30,000 in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He led them to Baalah of Judah to bring back the Ark of God, which bears the name of the Lord of Heaven’s Armies, who is enthroned between the cherubim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They placed the Ark of God on a new cart and brought it from Abinadab’s house, which was on a hill. Uzzah and Ahio, Abinadab’s sons, were guiding the cart
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: that carried the Ark of God. Ahio walked in front of the Ark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David and all the people of Israel were celebrating before the Lord, singing songs and playing all kinds of musical instruments—lyres, harps, tambourines, castanets, and cymbals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when they arrived at the threshing floor of Nacon, the oxen stumbled, and Uzzah reached out his hand and steadied the Ark of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord’s anger was aroused against Uzzah, and God struck him dead because of this. So Uzzah died right there beside the Ark of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was angry because the Lord’s anger had burst out against Uzzah. He named that place Perez-uzzah (which means “to burst out against Uzzah”), as it is still called today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was now afraid of the Lord, and he asked, “How can I ever bring the Ark of the Lord back into my care?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David decided not to move the Ark of the Lord into the City of David. Instead, he took it to the house of Obed-edom of Gath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Ark of the Lord remained there in Obed-edom’s house for three months, and the Lord blessed Obed-edom and his entire household.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King David was told, “The Lord has blessed Obed-edom’s household and everything he has because of the Ark of God.” So David went there and brought the Ark of God from the house of Obed-edom to the City of David with a great celebration.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the men who were carrying the Ark of the Lord had gone six steps, David sacrificed a bull and a fattened calf.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And David danced before the Lord with all his might, wearing a priestly garment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and all the people of Israel brought up the Ark of the Lord with shouts of joy and the blowing of rams’ horns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But as the Ark of the Lord entered the City of David, Michal, the daughter of Saul, looked down from her window. When she saw King David leaping and dancing before the Lord, she was filled with contempt for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought the Ark of the Lord and set it in its place inside the special tent David had prepared for it. And David sacrificed burnt offerings and peace offerings to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he had finished his sacrifices, David blessed the people in the name of the Lord of Heaven’s Armies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he gave to every Israelite man and woman in the crowd a loaf of bread, a cake of dates, and a cake of raisins. Then all the people returned to their homes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David returned home to bless his own family, Michal, the daughter of Saul, came out to meet him. She said in disgust, “How distinguished the king of Israel looked today, shamelessly exposing himself to the servant girls like any vulgar person might do!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David retorted to Michal, “I was dancing before the Lord, who chose me above your father and all his family! He appointed me as the leader of Israel, the people of the Lord, so I celebrate before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yes, and I am willing to look even more foolish than this, even to be humiliated in my own eyes! But those servant girls you mentioned will indeed think I am distinguished!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Michal, the daughter of Saul, remained childless throughout her entire life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King David was settled in his palace and the Lord had given him rest from all the surrounding enemies,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the king summoned Nathan the prophet. “Look,” David said, “I am living in a beautiful cedar palace, but the Ark of God is out there in a tent!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nathan replied to the king, “Go ahead and do whatever you have in mind, for the Lord is with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But that same night the Lord said to Nathan,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go and tell my servant David, ‘This is what the Lord has declared: Are you the one to build a house for me to live in?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have never lived in a house, from the day I brought the Israelites out of Egypt until this very day. I have always moved from one place to another with a tent and a Tabernacle as my dwelling.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet no matter where I have gone with the Israelites, I have never once complained to Israel’s tribal leaders, the shepherds of my people Israel. I have never asked them, “Why haven’t you built me a beautiful cedar house?”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now go and say to my servant David, ‘This is what the Lord of Heaven’s Armies has declared: I took you from tending sheep in the pasture and selected you to be the leader of my people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have been with you wherever you have gone, and I have destroyed all your enemies before your eyes. Now I will make your name as famous as anyone who has ever lived on the earth!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I will provide a homeland for my people Israel, planting them in a secure place where they will never be disturbed. Evil nations won’t oppress them as they’ve done in the past,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
starting from the time I appointed judges to rule my people Israel. And I will give you rest from all your enemies.
“‘Furthermore, the Lord declares that he will make a house for you—a dynasty of kings!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For when you die and are buried with your ancestors, I will raise up one of your descendants, your own offspring, and I will make his kingdom strong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He is the one who will build a house—a temple—for my name. And I will secure his royal throne forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will be his father, and he will be my son. If he sins, I will correct and discipline him with the rod, like any father would do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But my favor will not be taken from him as I took it from Saul, whom I removed from your sight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your house and your kingdom will continue before me for all time, and your throne will be secure forever.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Nathan went back to David and told him everything the Lord had said in this vision.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then King David went in and sat before the Lord and prayed,
“Who am I, O Sovereign Lord, and what is my family, that you have brought me this far?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now, Sovereign Lord, in addition to everything else, you speak of giving your servant a lasting dynasty! Do you deal with everyone this way, O Sovereign Lord?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “What more can I say to you? You know what your servant is really like, Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because of your promise and according to your will, you have done all these great things and have made them known to your servant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “How great you are, O Sovereign Lord! There is no one like you. We have never even heard of another God like you!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What other nation on earth is like your people Israel? What other nation, O God, have you redeemed from slavery to be your own people? You made a great name for yourself when you redeemed your people from Egypt. You performed awesome miracles and drove out the nations and gods that stood in their way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You made Israel your very own people forever, and you, O Lord, became their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And now, O Lord God, I am your servant; do as you have promised concerning me and my family. Confirm it as a promise that will last forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And may your name be honored forever so that everyone will say, ‘The Lord of Heaven’s Armies is God over Israel!’ And may the house of your servant David continue before you forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “O Lord of Heaven’s Armies, God of Israel, I have been bold enough to pray this prayer to you because you have revealed all this to your servant, saying, ‘I will build a house for you—a dynasty of kings!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For you are God, O Sovereign Lord. Your words are truth, and you have promised these good things to your servant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now, may it please you to bless the house of your servant, so that it may continue forever before you. For you have spoken, and when you grant a blessing to your servant, O Sovereign Lord, it is an eternal blessing!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, David defeated and subdued the Philistines by conquering Gath, their largest town.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David also conquered the land of Moab. He made the people lie down on the ground in a row, and he measured them off in groups with a length of rope. He measured off two groups to be executed for every one group to be spared. The Moabites who were spared became David’s subjects and paid him tribute money.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David also destroyed the forces of Hadadezer son of Rehob, king of Zobah, when Hadadezer marched out to strengthen his control along the Euphrates River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David captured 1,000 chariots, 7,000 charioteers, and 20,000 foot soldiers. He crippled all the chariot horses except enough for 100 chariots.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Arameans from Damascus arrived to help King Hadadezer, David killed 22,000 of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he placed several army garrisons in Damascus, the Aramean capital, and the Arameans became David’s subjects and paid him tribute money. So the Lord made David victorious wherever he went.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David brought the gold shields of Hadadezer’s officers to Jerusalem,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: along with a large amount of bronze from Hadadezer’s towns of Tebah and Berothai.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King Toi of Hamath heard that David had destroyed the entire army of Hadadezer,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he sent his son Joram to congratulate King David for his successful campaign. Hadadezer and Toi had been enemies and were often at war. Joram presented David with many gifts of silver, gold, and bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King David dedicated all these gifts to the Lord, as he did with the silver and gold from the other nations he had defeated—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: from Edom, Moab, Ammon, Philistia, and Amalek—and from Hadadezer son of Rehob, king of Zobah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David became even more famous when he returned from destroying 18,000 Edomites in the Valley of Salt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He placed army garrisons throughout Edom, and all the Edomites became David’s subjects. In fact, the Lord made David victorious wherever he went.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David reigned over all Israel and did what was just and right for all his people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab son of Zeruiah was commander of the army. Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was the royal historian.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zadok son of Ahitub and Ahimelech son of Abiathar were the priests. Seraiah was the court secretary.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Benaiah son of Jehoiada was captain of the king’s bodyguard. And David’s sons served as priestly leaders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day David asked, “Is anyone in Saul’s family still alive—anyone to whom I can show kindness for Jonathan’s sake?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He summoned a man named Ziba, who had been one of Saul’s servants. “Are you Ziba?” the king asked.
“Yes sir, I am,” Ziba replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king then asked him, “Is anyone still alive from Saul’s family? If so, I want to show God’s kindness to them.”
Ziba replied, “Yes, one of Jonathan’s sons is still alive. He is crippled in both feet.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Where is he?” the king asked.
“In Lo-debar,” Ziba told him, “at the home of Makir son of Ammiel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David sent for him and brought him from Makir’s home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His name was Mephibosheth; he was Jonathan’s son and Saul’s grandson. When he came to David, he bowed low to the ground in deep respect. David said, “Greetings, Mephibosheth.”
Mephibosheth replied, “I am your servant.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Don’t be afraid!” David said. “I intend to show kindness to you because of my promise to your father, Jonathan. I will give you all the property that once belonged to your grandfather Saul, and you will eat here with me at the king’s table!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mephibosheth bowed respectfully and exclaimed, “Who is your servant, that you should show such kindness to a dead dog like me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king summoned Saul’s servant Ziba and said, “I have given your master’s grandson everything that belonged to Saul and his family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You and your sons and servants are to farm the land for him to produce food for your master’s household. But Mephibosheth, your master’s grandson, will eat here at my table.” (Ziba had fifteen sons and twenty servants.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ziba replied, “Yes, my lord the king; I am your servant, and I will do all that you have commanded.” And from that time on, Mephibosheth ate regularly at David’s table, like one of the king’s own sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mephibosheth had a young son named Mica. From then on, all the members of Ziba’s household were Mephibosheth’s servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Mephibosheth, who was crippled in both feet, lived in Jerusalem and ate regularly at the king’s table.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some time after this, King Nahash of the Ammonites died, and his son Hanun became king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David said, “I am going to show loyalty to Hanun just as his father, Nahash, was always loyal to me.” So David sent ambassadors to express sympathy to Hanun about his father’s death.
But when David’s ambassadors arrived in the land of Ammon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the Ammonite commanders said to Hanun, their master, “Do you really think these men are coming here to honor your father? No! David has sent them to spy out the city so they can come in and conquer it!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Hanun seized David’s ambassadors and shaved off half of each man’s beard, cut off their robes at the buttocks, and sent them back to David in shame.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David heard what had happened, he sent messengers to tell the men, “Stay at Jericho until your beards grow out, and then come back.” For they felt deep shame because of their appearance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the people of Ammon realized how seriously they had angered David, they sent and hired 20,000 Aramean foot soldiers from the lands of Beth-rehob and Zobah, 1,000 from the king of Maacah, and 12,000 from the land of Tob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David heard about this, he sent Joab and all his warriors to fight them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Ammonite troops came out and drew up their battle lines at the entrance of the city gate, while the Arameans from Zobah and Rehob and the men from Tob and Maacah positioned themselves to fight in the open fields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joab saw that he would have to fight on both the front and the rear, he chose some of Israel’s elite troops and placed them under his personal command to fight the Arameans in the fields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He left the rest of the army under the command of his brother Abishai, who was to attack the Ammonites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If the Arameans are too strong for me, then come over and help me,” Joab told his brother. “And if the Ammonites are too strong for you, I will come and help you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Be courageous! Let us fight bravely for our people and the cities of our God. May the Lord’s will be done.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joab and his troops attacked, the Arameans began to run away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when the Ammonites saw the Arameans running, they ran from Abishai and retreated into the city. After the battle was over, Joab returned to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Arameans now realized that they were no match for Israel. So when they regrouped,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: they were joined by additional Aramean troops summoned by Hadadezer from the other side of the Euphrates River. These troops arrived at Helam under the command of Shobach, the commander of Hadadezer’s forces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David heard what was happening, he mobilized all Israel, crossed the Jordan River, and led the army to Helam. The Arameans positioned themselves in battle formation and fought against David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But again the Arameans fled from the Israelites. This time David’s forces killed 700 charioteers and 40,000 foot soldiers, including Shobach, the commander of their army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the kings allied with Hadadezer saw that they had been defeated by Israel, they surrendered to Israel and became their subjects. After that, the Arameans were afraid to help the Ammonites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the spring of the year, when kings normally go out to war, David sent Joab and the Israelite army to fight the Ammonites. They destroyed the Ammonite army and laid siege to the city of Rabbah. However, David stayed behind in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Late one afternoon, after his midday rest, David got out of bed and was walking on the roof of the palace. As he looked out over the city, he noticed a woman of unusual beauty taking a bath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sent someone to find out who she was, and he was told, “She is Bathsheba, the daughter of Eliam and the wife of Uriah the Hittite.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David sent messengers to get her; and when she came to the palace, he slept with her. She had just completed the purification rites after having her menstrual period. Then she returned home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later, when Bathsheba discovered that she was pregnant, she sent David a message, saying, “I’m pregnant.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David sent word to Joab: “Send me Uriah the Hittite.” So Joab sent him to David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Uriah arrived, David asked him how Joab and the army were getting along and how the war was progressing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he told Uriah, “Go on home and relax.” David even sent a gift to Uriah after he had left the palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Uriah didn’t go home. He slept that night at the palace entrance with the king’s palace guard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David heard that Uriah had not gone home, he summoned him and asked, “What’s the matter? Why didn’t you go home last night after being away for so long?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uriah replied, “The Ark and the armies of Israel and Judah are living in tents, and Joab and my master’s men are camping in the open fields. How could I go home to wine and dine and sleep with my wife? I swear that I would never do such a thing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Well, stay here today,” David told him, “and tomorrow you may return to the army.” So Uriah stayed in Jerusalem that day and the next.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David invited him to dinner and got him drunk. But even then he couldn’t get Uriah to go home to his wife. Again he slept at the palace entrance with the king’s palace guard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the next morning David wrote a letter to Joab and gave it to Uriah to deliver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The letter instructed Joab, “Station Uriah on the front lines where the battle is fiercest. Then pull back so that he will be killed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab assigned Uriah to a spot close to the city wall where he knew the enemy’s strongest men were fighting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when the enemy soldiers came out of the city to fight, Uriah the Hittite was killed along with several other Israelite soldiers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab sent a battle report to David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He told his messenger, “Report all the news of the battle to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he might get angry and ask, ‘Why did the troops go so close to the city? Didn’t they know there would be shooting from the walls?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Wasn’t Abimelech son of Gideon killed at Thebez by a woman who threw a millstone down on him from the wall? Why would you get so close to the wall?’ Then tell him, ‘Uriah the Hittite was killed, too.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the messenger went to Jerusalem and gave a complete report to David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The enemy came out against us in the open fields,” he said. “And as we chased them back to the city gate,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the archers on the wall shot arrows at us. Some of the king’s men were killed, including Uriah the Hittite.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Well, tell Joab not to be discouraged,” David said. “The sword devours this one today and that one tomorrow! Fight harder next time, and conquer the city!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Uriah’s wife heard that her husband was dead, she mourned for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the period of mourning was over, David sent for her and brought her to the palace, and she became one of his wives. Then she gave birth to a son. But the Lord was displeased with what David had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord sent Nathan the prophet to tell David this story: “There were two men in a certain town. One was rich, and one was poor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rich man owned a great many sheep and cattle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The poor man owned nothing but one little lamb he had bought. He raised that little lamb, and it grew up with his children. It ate from the man’s own plate and drank from his cup. He cuddled it in his arms like a baby daughter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day a guest arrived at the home of the rich man. But instead of killing an animal from his own flock or herd, he took the poor man’s lamb and killed it and prepared it for his guest.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was furious. “As surely as the Lord lives,” he vowed, “any man who would do such a thing deserves to die!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He must repay four lambs to the poor man for the one he stole and for having no pity.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Nathan said to David, “You are that man! The Lord, the God of Israel, says: I anointed you king of Israel and saved you from the power of Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I gave you your master’s house and his wives and the kingdoms of Israel and Judah. And if that had not been enough, I would have given you much, much more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why, then, have you despised the word of the Lord and done this horrible deed? For you have murdered Uriah the Hittite with the sword of the Ammonites and stolen his wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From this time on, your family will live by the sword because you have despised me by taking Uriah’s wife to be your own.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord says: Because of what you have done, I will cause your own household to rebel against you. I will give your wives to another man before your very eyes, and he will go to bed with them in public view.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You did it secretly, but I will make this happen to you openly in the sight of all Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then David confessed to Nathan, “I have sinned against the Lord.”
Nathan replied, “Yes, but the Lord has forgiven you, and you won’t die for this sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, because you have shown utter contempt for the word of the Lord by doing this, your child will die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Nathan returned to his home, the Lord sent a deadly illness to the child of David and Uriah’s wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David begged God to spare the child. He went without food and lay all night on the bare ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The elders of his household pleaded with him to get up and eat with them, but he refused.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then on the seventh day the child died. David’s advisers were afraid to tell him. “He wouldn’t listen to reason while the child was ill,” they said. “What drastic thing will he do when we tell him the child is dead?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When David saw them whispering, he realized what had happened. “Is the child dead?” he asked.
“Yes,” they replied, “he is dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David got up from the ground, washed himself, put on lotions, and changed his clothes. He went to the Tabernacle and worshiped the Lord. After that, he returned to the palace and was served food and ate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His advisers were amazed. “We don’t understand you,” they told him. “While the child was still living, you wept and refused to eat. But now that the child is dead, you have stopped your mourning and are eating again.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David replied, “I fasted and wept while the child was alive, for I said, ‘Perhaps the Lord will be gracious to me and let the child live.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But why should I fast when he is dead? Can I bring him back again? I will go to him one day, but he cannot return to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David comforted Bathsheba, his wife, and slept with her. She became pregnant and gave birth to a son, and David named him Solomon. The Lord loved the child
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and sent word through Nathan the prophet that they should name him Jedidiah (which means “beloved of the Lord”), as the Lord had commanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, Joab was fighting against Rabbah, the capital of Ammon, and he captured the royal fortifications.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab sent messengers to tell David, “I have fought against Rabbah and captured its water supply.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now bring the rest of the army and capture the city. Otherwise, I will capture it and get credit for the victory.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David gathered the rest of the army and went to Rabbah, and he fought against it and captured it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David removed the crown from the king’s head, and it was placed on his own head. The crown was made of gold and set with gems, and it weighed seventy-five pounds. David took a vast amount of plunder from the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also made slaves of the people of Rabbah and forced them to labor with saws, iron picks, and iron axes, and to work in the brick kilns. That is how he dealt with the people of all the Ammonite towns. Then David and all the army returned to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now David’s son Absalom had a beautiful sister named Tamar. And Amnon, her half brother, fell desperately in love with her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amnon became so obsessed with Tamar that he became ill. She was a virgin, and Amnon thought he could never have her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Amnon had a very crafty friend—his cousin Jonadab. He was the son of David’s brother Shimea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
One day Jonadab said to Amnon, “What’s the trouble? Why should the son of a king look so dejected morning after morning?”
So Amnon told him, “I am in love with Tamar, my brother Absalom’s sister.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Well,” Jonadab said, “I’ll tell you what to do. Go back to bed and pretend you are ill. When your father comes to see you, ask him to let Tamar come and prepare some food for you. Tell him you’ll feel better if she prepares it as you watch and feeds you with her own hands.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Amnon lay down and pretended to be sick. And when the king came to see him, Amnon asked him, “Please let my sister Tamar come and cook my favorite dish as I watch. Then I can eat it from her own hands.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David agreed and sent Tamar to Amnon’s house to prepare some food for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Tamar arrived at Amnon’s house, she went to the place where he was lying down so he could watch her mix some dough. Then she baked his favorite dish for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when she set the serving tray before him, he refused to eat. “Everyone get out of here,” Amnon told his servants. So they all left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said to Tamar, “Now bring the food into my bedroom and feed it to me here.” So Tamar took his favorite dish to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But as she was feeding him, he grabbed her and demanded, “Come to bed with me, my darling sister.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “No, my brother!” she cried. “Don’t be foolish! Don’t do this to me! Such wicked things aren’t done in Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Where could I go in my shame? And you would be called one of the greatest fools in Israel. Please, just speak to the king about it, and he will let you marry me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Amnon wouldn’t listen to her, and since he was stronger than she was, he raped her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then suddenly Amnon’s love turned to hate, and he hated her even more than he had loved her. “Get out of here!” he snarled at her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“No, no!” Tamar cried. “Sending me away now is worse than what you’ve already done to me.”
But Amnon wouldn’t listen to her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He shouted for his servant and demanded, “Throw this woman out, and lock the door behind her!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the servant put her out and locked the door behind her. She was wearing a long, beautiful robe, as was the custom in those days for the king’s virgin daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now Tamar tore her robe and put ashes on her head. And then, with her face in her hands, she went away crying.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Her brother Absalom saw her and asked, “Is it true that Amnon has been with you? Well, my sister, keep quiet for now, since he’s your brother. Don’t you worry about it.” So Tamar lived as a desolate woman in her brother Absalom’s house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King David heard what had happened, he was very angry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And though Absalom never spoke to Amnon about this, he hated Amnon deeply because of what he had done to his sister.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Two years later, when Absalom’s sheep were being sheared at Baal-hazor near Ephraim, Absalom invited all the king’s sons to come to a feast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He went to the king and said, “My sheep-shearers are now at work. Would the king and his servants please come to celebrate the occasion with me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king replied, “No, my son. If we all came, we would be too much of a burden on you.” Absalom pressed him, but the king would not come, though he gave Absalom his blessing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Well, then,” Absalom said, “if you can’t come, how about sending my brother Amnon with us?”
“Why Amnon?” the king asked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Absalom kept on pressing the king until he finally agreed to let all his sons attend, including Amnon. So Absalom prepared a feast fit for a king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom told his men, “Wait until Amnon gets drunk; then at my signal, kill him! Don’t be afraid. I’m the one who has given the command. Take courage and do it!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So at Absalom’s signal they murdered Amnon. Then the other sons of the king jumped on their mules and fled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they were on the way back to Jerusalem, this report reached David: “Absalom has killed all the king’s sons; not one is left alive!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king got up, tore his robe, and threw himself on the ground. His advisers also tore their clothes in horror and sorrow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But just then Jonadab, the son of David’s brother Shimea, arrived and said, “No, don’t believe that all the king’s sons have been killed! It was only Amnon! Absalom has been plotting this ever since Amnon raped his sister Tamar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No, my lord the king, your sons aren’t all dead! It was only Amnon.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Meanwhile Absalom escaped.
Then the watchman on the Jerusalem wall saw a great crowd coming down the hill on the road from the west. He ran to tell the king, “I see a crowd of people coming from the Horonaim road along the side of the hill.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Look!” Jonadab told the king. “There they are now! The king’s sons are coming, just as I said.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They soon arrived, weeping and sobbing, and the king and all his servants wept bitterly with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And David mourned many days for his son Amnon.
Absalom fled to his grandfather, Talmai son of Ammihud, the king of Geshur.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He stayed there in Geshur for three years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And King David, now reconciled to Amnon’s death, longed to be reunited with his son Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab realized how much the king longed to see Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he sent for a woman from Tekoa who had a reputation for great wisdom. He said to her, “Pretend you are in mourning; wear mourning clothes and don’t put on lotions. Act like a woman who has been mourning for the dead for a long time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then go to the king and tell him the story I am about to tell you.” Then Joab told her what to say.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the woman from Tekoa approached the king, she bowed with her face to the ground in deep respect and cried out, “O king! Help me!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“What’s the trouble?” the king asked.
“Alas, I am a widow!” she replied. “My husband is dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My two sons had a fight out in the field. And since no one was there to stop it, one of them was killed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the rest of the family is demanding, ‘Let us have your son. We will execute him for murdering his brother. He doesn’t deserve to inherit his family’s property.’ They want to extinguish the only coal I have left, and my husband’s name and family will disappear from the face of the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Leave it to me,” the king told her. “Go home, and I’ll see to it that no one touches him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Oh, thank you, my lord the king,” the woman from Tekoa replied. “If you are criticized for helping me, let the blame fall on me and on my father’s house, and let the king and his throne be innocent.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If anyone objects,” the king said, “bring him to me. I can assure you he will never harm you again!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then she said, “Please swear to me by the Lord your God that you won’t let anyone take vengeance against my son. I want no more bloodshed.”
“As surely as the Lord lives,” he replied, “not a hair on your son’s head will be disturbed!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Please allow me to ask one more thing of my lord the king,” she said.
“Go ahead and speak,” he responded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She replied, “Why don’t you do as much for the people of God as you have promised to do for me? You have convicted yourself in making this decision, because you have refused to bring home your own banished son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All of us must die eventually. Our lives are like water spilled out on the ground, which cannot be gathered up again. But God does not just sweep life away; instead, he devises ways to bring us back when we have been separated from him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I have come to plead with my lord the king because people have threatened me. I said to myself, ‘Perhaps the king will listen to me
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and rescue us from those who would cut us off from the inheritance God has given us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yes, my lord the king will give us peace of mind again.’ I know that you are like an angel of God in discerning good from evil. May the Lord your God be with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I must know one thing,” the king replied, “and tell me the truth.”
“Yes, my lord the king,” she responded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Did Joab put you up to this?”
And the woman replied, “My lord the king, how can I deny it? Nobody can hide anything from you. Yes, Joab sent me and told me what to say.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did it to place the matter before you in a different light. But you are as wise as an angel of God, and you understand everything that happens among us!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king sent for Joab and told him, “All right, go and bring back the young man Absalom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab bowed with his face to the ground in deep respect and said, “At last I know that I have gained your approval, my lord the king, for you have granted me this request!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab went to Geshur and brought Absalom back to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king gave this order: “Absalom may go to his own house, but he must never come into my presence.” So Absalom did not see the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Absalom was praised as the most handsome man in all Israel. He was flawless from head to foot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He cut his hair only once a year, and then only because it was so heavy. When he weighed it out, it came to five pounds!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had three sons and one daughter. His daughter’s name was Tamar, and she was very beautiful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom lived in Jerusalem for two years, but he never got to see the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom sent for Joab to ask him to intercede for him, but Joab refused to come. Absalom sent for him a second time, but again Joab refused to come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Absalom said to his servants, “Go and set fire to Joab’s barley field, the field next to mine.” So they set his field on fire, as Absalom had commanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab came to Absalom at his house and demanded, “Why did your servants set my field on fire?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Absalom replied, “Because I wanted you to ask the king why he brought me back from Geshur if he didn’t intend to see me. I might as well have stayed there. Let me see the king; if he finds me guilty of anything, then let him kill me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab told the king what Absalom had said. Then at last David summoned Absalom, who came and bowed low before the king, and the king kissed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, Absalom bought a chariot and horses, and he hired fifty bodyguards to run ahead of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He got up early every morning and went out to the gate of the city. When people brought a case to the king for judgment, Absalom would ask where in Israel they were from, and they would tell him their tribe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom would say, “You’ve really got a strong case here! It’s too bad the king doesn’t have anyone to hear it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I wish I were the judge. Then everyone could bring their cases to me for judgment, and I would give them justice!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When people tried to bow before him, Absalom wouldn’t let them. Instead, he took them by the hand and kissed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom did this with everyone who came to the king for judgment, and so he stole the hearts of all the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After four years, Absalom said to the king, “Let me go to Hebron to offer a sacrifice to the Lord and fulfill a vow I made to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For while your servant was at Geshur in Aram, I promised to sacrifice to the Lord in Hebron if he would bring me back to Jerusalem.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“All right,” the king told him. “Go and fulfill your vow.”
So Absalom went to Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But while he was there, he sent secret messengers to all the tribes of Israel to stir up a rebellion against the king. “As soon as you hear the ram’s horn,” his message read, “you are to say, ‘Absalom has been crowned king in Hebron.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took 200 men from Jerusalem with him as guests, but they knew nothing of his intentions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Absalom was offering the sacrifices, he sent for Ahithophel, one of David’s counselors who lived in Giloh. Soon many others also joined Absalom, and the conspiracy gained momentum.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A messenger soon arrived in Jerusalem to tell David, “All Israel has joined Absalom in a conspiracy against you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then we must flee at once, or it will be too late!” David urged his men. “Hurry! If we get out of the city before Absalom arrives, both we and the city of Jerusalem will be spared from disaster.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “We are with you,” his advisers replied. “Do what you think is best.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king and all his household set out at once. He left no one behind except ten of his concubines to look after the palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king and all his people set out on foot, pausing at the last house
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: to let all the king’s men move past to lead the way. There were 600 men from Gath who had come with David, along with the king’s bodyguard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king turned and said to Ittai, a leader of the men from Gath, “Why are you coming with us? Go on back to King Absalom, for you are a guest in Israel, a foreigner in exile.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You arrived only recently, and should I force you today to wander with us? I don’t even know where we will go. Go on back and take your kinsmen with you, and may the Lord show you his unfailing love and faithfulness.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Ittai said to the king, “I vow by the Lord and by your own life that I will go wherever my lord the king goes, no matter what happens—whether it means life or death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David replied, “All right, come with us.” So Ittai and all his men and their families went along.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everyone cried loudly as the king and his followers passed by. They crossed the Kidron Valley and then went out toward the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zadok and all the Levites also came along, carrying the Ark of the Covenant of God. They set down the Ark of God, and Abiathar offered sacrifices until everyone had passed out of the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king instructed Zadok to take the Ark of God back into the city. “If the Lord sees fit,” David said, “he will bring me back to see the Ark and the Tabernacle again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if he is through with me, then let him do what seems best to him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king also told Zadok the priest, “Look, here is my plan. You and Abiathar should return quietly to the city with your son Ahimaaz and Abiathar’s son Jonathan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will stop at the shallows of the Jordan River and wait there for a report from you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Zadok and Abiathar took the Ark of God back to the city and stayed there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David walked up the road to the Mount of Olives, weeping as he went. His head was covered and his feet were bare as a sign of mourning. And the people who were with him covered their heads and wept as they climbed the hill.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When someone told David that his adviser Ahithophel was now backing Absalom, David prayed, “O Lord, let Ahithophel give Absalom foolish advice!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David reached the summit of the Mount of Olives where people worshiped God, Hushai the Arkite was waiting there for him. Hushai had torn his clothing and put dirt on his head as a sign of mourning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But David told him, “If you go with me, you will only be a burden.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Return to Jerusalem and tell Absalom, ‘I will now be your adviser, O king, just as I was your father’s adviser in the past.’ Then you can frustrate and counter Ahithophel’s advice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zadok and Abiathar, the priests, will be there. Tell them about the plans being made in the king’s palace,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and they will send their sons Ahimaaz and Jonathan to tell me what is going on.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David’s friend Hushai returned to Jerusalem, getting there just as Absalom arrived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David had gone a little beyond the summit of the Mount of Olives, Ziba, the servant of Mephibosheth, was waiting there for him. He had two donkeys loaded with 200 loaves of bread, 100 clusters of raisins, 100 bunches of summer fruit, and a wineskin full of wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“What are these for?” the king asked Ziba.
Ziba replied, “The donkeys are for the king’s people to ride on, and the bread and summer fruit are for the young men to eat. The wine is for those who become exhausted in the wilderness.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“And where is Mephibosheth, Saul’s grandson?” the king asked him.
“He stayed in Jerusalem,” Ziba replied. “He said, ‘Today I will get back the kingdom of my grandfather Saul.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“In that case,” the king told Ziba, “I give you everything Mephibosheth owns.”
“I bow before you,” Ziba replied. “May I always be pleasing to you, my lord the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As King David came to Bahurim, a man came out of the village cursing them. It was Shimei son of Gera, from the same clan as Saul’s family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He threw stones at the king and the king’s officers and all the mighty warriors who surrounded him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Get out of here, you murderer, you scoundrel!” he shouted at David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The Lord is paying you back for all the bloodshed in Saul’s clan. You stole his throne, and now the Lord has given it to your son Absalom. At last you will taste some of your own medicine, for you are a murderer!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Why should this dead dog curse my lord the king?” Abishai son of Zeruiah demanded. “Let me go over and cut off his head!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “No!” the king said. “Who asked your opinion, you sons of Zeruiah! If the Lord has told him to curse me, who are you to stop him?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to Abishai and to all his servants, “My own son is trying to kill me. Doesn’t this relative of Saul have even more reason to do so? Leave him alone and let him curse, for the Lord has told him to do it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And perhaps the Lord will see that I am being wronged and will bless me because of these curses today.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and his men continued down the road, and Shimei kept pace with them on a nearby hillside, cursing and throwing stones and dirt at David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king and all who were with him grew weary along the way, so they rested when they reached the Jordan River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, Absalom and all the army of Israel arrived at Jerusalem, accompanied by Ahithophel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David’s friend Hushai the Arkite arrived, he went immediately to see Absalom. “Long live the king!” he exclaimed. “Long live the king!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Is this the way you treat your friend David?” Absalom asked him. “Why aren’t you with him?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I’m here because I belong to the man who is chosen by the Lord and by all the men of Israel,” Hushai replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And anyway, why shouldn’t I serve you? Just as I was your father’s adviser, now I will be your adviser!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom turned to Ahithophel and asked him, “What should I do next?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahithophel told him, “Go and sleep with your father’s concubines, for he has left them here to look after the palace. Then all Israel will know that you have insulted your father beyond hope of reconciliation, and they will throw their support to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they set up a tent on the palace roof where everyone could see it, and Absalom went in and had sex with his father’s concubines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom followed Ahithophel’s advice, just as David had done. For every word Ahithophel spoke seemed as wise as though it had come directly from the mouth of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Ahithophel urged Absalom, “Let me choose 12,000 men to start out after David tonight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will catch up with him while he is weary and discouraged. He and his troops will panic, and everyone will run away. Then I will kill only the king,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and I will bring all the people back to you as a bride returns to her husband. After all, it is only one man’s life that you seek. Then you will be at peace with all the people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This plan seemed good to Absalom and to all the elders of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But then Absalom said, “Bring in Hushai the Arkite. Let’s see what he thinks about this.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Hushai arrived, Absalom told him what Ahithophel had said. Then he asked, “What is your opinion? Should we follow Ahithophel’s advice? If not, what do you suggest?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Well,” Hushai replied to Absalom, “this time Ahithophel has made a mistake.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You know your father and his men; they are mighty warriors. Right now they are as enraged as a mother bear who has been robbed of her cubs. And remember that your father is an experienced man of war. He won’t be spending the night among the troops.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He has probably already hidden in some pit or cave. And when he comes out and attacks and a few of your men fall, there will be panic among your troops, and the word will spread that Absalom’s men are being slaughtered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then even the bravest soldiers, though they have the heart of a lion, will be paralyzed with fear. For all Israel knows what a mighty warrior your father is and how courageous his men are.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I recommend that you mobilize the entire army of Israel, bringing them from as far away as Dan in the north and Beersheba in the south. That way you will have an army as numerous as the sand on the seashore. And I advise that you personally lead the troops.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we find David, we’ll fall on him like dew that falls on the ground. Then neither he nor any of his men will be left alive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And if David were to escape into some town, you will have all Israel there at your command. Then we can take ropes and drag the walls of the town into the nearest valley until every stone is torn down.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom and all the men of Israel said, “Hushai’s advice is better than Ahithophel’s.” For the Lord had determined to defeat the counsel of Ahithophel, which really was the better plan, so that he could bring disaster on Absalom!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hushai told Zadok and Abiathar, the priests, what Ahithophel had said to Absalom and the elders of Israel and what he himself had advised instead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Quick!” he told them. “Find David and urge him not to stay at the shallows of the Jordan River tonight. He must go across at once into the wilderness beyond. Otherwise he will die and his entire army with him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan and Ahimaaz had been staying at En-rogel so as not to be seen entering and leaving the city. Arrangements had been made for a servant girl to bring them the message they were to take to King David.
verses.speaker: Narrator
