verses.text: But a boy spotted them at En-rogel, and he told Absalom about it. So they quickly escaped to Bahurim, where a man hid them down inside a well in his courtyard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man’s wife put a cloth over the top of the well and scattered grain on it to dry in the sun; so no one suspected they were there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When Absalom’s men arrived, they asked her, “Have you seen Ahimaaz and Jonathan?”
The woman replied, “They were here, but they crossed over the brook.” Absalom’s men looked for them without success and returned to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the two men crawled out of the well and hurried on to King David. “Quick!” they told him, “cross the Jordan tonight!” And they told him how Ahithophel had advised that he be captured and killed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and all the people with him went across the Jordan River during the night, and they were all on the other bank before dawn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ahithophel realized that his advice had not been followed, he saddled his donkey, went to his hometown, set his affairs in order, and hanged himself. He died there and was buried in the family tomb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David soon arrived at Mahanaim. By now, Absalom had mobilized the entire army of Israel and was leading his troops across the Jordan River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom had appointed Amasa as commander of his army, replacing Joab, who had been commander under David. (Amasa was Joab’s cousin. His father was Jether, an Ishmaelite. His mother, Abigail daughter of Nahash, was the sister of Joab’s mother, Zeruiah.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom and the Israelite army set up camp in the land of Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David arrived at Mahanaim, he was warmly greeted by Shobi son of Nahash, who came from Rabbah of the Ammonites, and by Makir son of Ammiel from Lo-debar, and by Barzillai of Gilead from Rogelim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought sleeping mats, cooking pots, serving bowls, wheat and barley, flour and roasted grain, beans, lentils,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: honey, butter, sheep, goats, and cheese for David and those who were with him. For they said, “You must all be very hungry and tired and thirsty after your long march through the wilderness.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David now mustered the men who were with him and appointed generals and captains to lead them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sent the troops out in three groups, placing one group under Joab, one under Joab’s brother Abishai son of Zeruiah, and one under Ittai, the man from Gath. The king told his troops, “I am going out with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But his men objected strongly. “You must not go,” they urged. “If we have to turn and run—and even if half of us die—it will make no difference to Absalom’s troops; they will be looking only for you. You are worth 10,000 of us, and it is better that you stay here in the town and send help if we need it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If you think that’s the best plan, I’ll do it,” the king answered. So he stood alongside the gate of the town as all the troops marched out in groups of hundreds and of thousands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the king gave this command to Joab, Abishai, and Ittai: “For my sake, deal gently with young Absalom.” And all the troops heard the king give this order to his commanders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the battle began in the forest of Ephraim,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the Israelite troops were beaten back by David’s men. There was a great slaughter that day, and 20,000 men laid down their lives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The battle raged all across the countryside, and more men died because of the forest than were killed by the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During the battle, Absalom happened to come upon some of David’s men. He tried to escape on his mule, but as he rode beneath the thick branches of a great tree, his hair got caught in the tree. His mule kept going and left him dangling in the air.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One of David’s men saw what had happened and told Joab, “I saw Absalom dangling from a great tree.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “What?” Joab demanded. “You saw him there and didn’t kill him? I would have rewarded you with ten pieces of silver and a hero’s belt!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I would not kill the king’s son for even a thousand pieces of silver,” the man replied to Joab. “We all heard the king say to you and Abishai and Ittai, ‘For my sake, please spare young Absalom.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And if I had betrayed the king by killing his son—and the king would certainly find out who did it—you yourself would be the first to abandon me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Enough of this nonsense,” Joab said. Then he took three daggers and plunged them into Absalom’s heart as he dangled, still alive, in the great tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ten of Joab’s young armor bearers then surrounded Absalom and killed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab blew the ram’s horn, and his men returned from chasing the army of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They threw Absalom’s body into a deep pit in the forest and piled a great heap of stones over it. And all Israel fled to their homes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During his lifetime, Absalom had built a monument to himself in the King’s Valley, for he said, “I have no son to carry on my name.” He named the monument after himself, and it is known as Absalom’s Monument to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Zadok’s son Ahimaaz said, “Let me run to the king with the good news that the Lord has rescued him from his enemies.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “No,” Joab told him, “it wouldn’t be good news to the king that his son is dead. You can be my messenger another time, but not today.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab said to a man from Ethiopia, “Go tell the king what you have seen.” The man bowed and ran off.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But Ahimaaz continued to plead with Joab, “Whatever happens, please let me go, too.”
“Why should you go, my son?” Joab replied. “There will be no reward for your news.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Yes, but let me go anyway,” he begged.
Joab finally said, “All right, go ahead.” So Ahimaaz took the less demanding route by way of the plain and ran to Mahanaim ahead of the Ethiopian.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While David was sitting between the inner and outer gates of the town, the watchman climbed to the roof of the gateway by the wall. As he looked, he saw a lone man running toward them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He shouted the news down to David, and the king replied, “If he is alone, he has news.”
As the messenger came closer,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the watchman saw another man running toward them. He shouted down, “Here comes another one!”
The king replied, “He also will have news.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The first man runs like Ahimaaz son of Zadok,” the watchman said.
“He is a good man and comes with good news,” the king replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ahimaaz cried out to the king, “Everything is all right!” He bowed before the king with his face to the ground and said, “Praise to the Lord your God, who has handed over the rebels who dared to stand against my lord the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“What about young Absalom?” the king demanded. “Is he all right?”
Ahimaaz replied, “When Joab told me to come, there was a lot of commotion. But I didn’t know what was happening.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Wait here,” the king told him. So Ahimaaz stepped aside.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the man from Ethiopia arrived and said, “I have good news for my lord the king. Today the Lord has rescued you from all those who rebelled against you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“What about young Absalom?” the king demanded. “Is he all right?”
And the Ethiopian replied, “May all of your enemies, my lord the king, both now and in the future, share the fate of that young man!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king was overcome with emotion. He went up to the room over the gateway and burst into tears. And as he went, he cried, “O my son Absalom! My son, my son Absalom! If only I had died instead of you! O Absalom, my son, my son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Word soon reached Joab that the king was weeping and mourning for Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As all the people heard of the king’s deep grief for his son, the joy of that day’s victory was turned into deep sadness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They crept back into the town that day as though they were ashamed and had deserted in battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king covered his face with his hands and kept on crying, “O my son Absalom! O Absalom, my son, my son!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab went to the king’s room and said to him, “We saved your life today and the lives of your sons, your daughters, and your wives and concubines. Yet you act like this, making us feel ashamed of ourselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You seem to love those who hate you and hate those who love you. You have made it clear today that your commanders and troops mean nothing to you. It seems that if Absalom had lived and all of us had died, you would be pleased.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now go out there and congratulate your troops, for I swear by the Lord that if you don’t go out, not a single one of them will remain here tonight. Then you will be worse off than ever before.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So the king went out and took his seat at the town gate, and as the news spread throughout the town that he was there, everyone went to him.
Meanwhile, the Israelites who had supported Absalom fled to their homes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And throughout all the tribes of Israel there was much discussion and argument going on. The people were saying, “The king rescued us from our enemies and saved us from the Philistines, but Absalom chased him out of the country.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Absalom, whom we anointed to rule over us, is dead. Why not ask David to come back and be our king again?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King David sent Zadok and Abiathar, the priests, to say to the elders of Judah, “Why are you the last ones to welcome back the king into his palace? For I have heard that all Israel is ready.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are my relatives, my own tribe, my own flesh and blood! So why are you the last ones to welcome back the king?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And David told them to tell Amasa, “Since you are my own flesh and blood, like Joab, may God strike me and even kill me if I do not appoint you as commander of my army in his place.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Amasa convinced all the men of Judah, and they responded unanimously. They sent word to the king, “Return to us, and bring back all who are with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king started back to Jerusalem. And when he arrived at the Jordan River, the people of Judah came to Gilgal to meet him and escort him across the river.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shimei son of Gera, the man from Bahurim in Benjamin, hurried across with the men of Judah to welcome King David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A thousand other men from the tribe of Benjamin were with him, including Ziba, the chief servant of the house of Saul, and Ziba’s fifteen sons and twenty servants. They rushed down to the Jordan to meet the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They crossed the shallows of the Jordan to bring the king’s household across the river, helping him in every way they could.
As the king was about to cross the river, Shimei fell down before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “My lord the king, please forgive me,” he pleaded. “Forget the terrible thing your servant did when you left Jerusalem. May the king put it out of his mind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I know how much I sinned. That is why I have come here today, the very first person in all Israel to greet my lord the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abishai son of Zeruiah said, “Shimei should die, for he cursed the Lord’s anointed king!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Who asked your opinion, you sons of Zeruiah!” David exclaimed. “Why have you become my adversary today? This is not a day for execution, for today I am once again the king of Israel!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then, turning to Shimei, David vowed, “Your life will be spared.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Mephibosheth, Saul’s grandson, came down from Jerusalem to meet the king. He had not cared for his feet, trimmed his beard, or washed his clothes since the day the king left Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Why didn’t you come with me, Mephibosheth?” the king asked him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mephibosheth replied, “My lord the king, my servant Ziba deceived me. I told him, ‘Saddle my donkey so I can go with the king.’ For as you know I am crippled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ziba has slandered me by saying that I refused to come. But I know that my lord the king is like an angel of God, so do what you think is best.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All my relatives and I could expect only death from you, my lord, but instead you have honored me by allowing me to eat at your own table! What more can I ask?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You’ve said enough,” David replied. “I’ve decided that you and Ziba will divide your land equally between you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Give him all of it,” Mephibosheth said. “I am content just to have you safely back again, my lord the king!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Barzillai of Gilead had come down from Rogelim to escort the king across the Jordan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was very old—eighty years of age—and very wealthy. He was the one who had provided food for the king during his stay in Mahanaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Come across with me and live in Jerusalem,” the king said to Barzillai. “I will take care of you there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “No,” he replied, “I am far too old to go with the king to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am eighty years old today, and I can no longer enjoy anything. Food and wine are no longer tasty, and I cannot hear the singers as they sing. I would only be a burden to my lord the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just to go across the Jordan River with the king is all the honor I need!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then let me return again to die in my own town, where my father and mother are buried. But here is your servant, my son Kimham. Let him go with my lord the king and receive whatever you want to give him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Good,” the king agreed. “Kimham will go with me, and I will help him in any way you would like. And I will do for you anything you want.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the people crossed the Jordan with the king. After David had blessed Barzillai and kissed him, Barzillai returned to his own home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king then crossed over to Gilgal, taking Kimham with him. All the troops of Judah and half the troops of Israel escorted the king on his way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But all the men of Israel complained to the king, “The men of Judah stole the king and didn’t give us the honor of helping take you, your household, and all your men across the Jordan.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of Judah replied, “The king is one of our own kinsmen. Why should this make you angry? We haven’t eaten any of the king’s food or received any special favors!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But there are ten tribes in Israel,” the others replied. “So we have ten times as much right to the king as you do. What right do you have to treat us with such contempt? Weren’t we the first to speak of bringing him back to be our king again?” The argument continued back and forth, and the men of Judah spoke even more harshly than the men of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There happened to be a troublemaker there named Sheba son of Bicri, a man from the tribe of Benjamin. Sheba blew a ram’s horn and began to chant: 
“Down with the dynasty of David!
    We have no interest in the son of Jesse.
Come on, you men of Israel,
    back to your homes!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the men of Israel deserted David and followed Sheba son of Bicri. But the men of Judah stayed with their king and escorted him from the Jordan River to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David came to his palace in Jerusalem, he took the ten concubines he had left to look after the palace and placed them in seclusion. Their needs were provided for, but he no longer slept with them. So each of them lived like a widow until she died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king told Amasa, “Mobilize the army of Judah within three days, and report back at that time.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Amasa went out to notify Judah, but it took him longer than the time he had been given.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to Abishai, “Sheba son of Bicri is going to hurt us more than Absalom did. Quick, take my troops and chase after him before he gets into a fortified town where we can’t reach him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abishai and Joab, together with the king’s bodyguard and all the mighty warriors, set out from Jerusalem to go after Sheba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they arrived at the great stone in Gibeon, Amasa met them. Joab was wearing his military tunic with a dagger strapped to his belt. As he stepped forward to greet Amasa, he slipped the dagger from its sheath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “How are you, my cousin?” Joab said and took him by the beard with his right hand as though to kiss him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amasa didn’t notice the dagger in his left hand, and Joab stabbed him in the stomach with it so that his insides gushed out onto the ground. Joab did not need to strike again, and Amasa soon died. Joab and his brother Abishai left him lying there and continued after Sheba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One of Joab’s young men shouted to Amasa’s troops, “If you are for Joab and David, come and follow Joab.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Amasa lay in his blood in the middle of the road, and Joab’s man saw that everyone was stopping to stare at him. So he pulled him off the road into a field and threw a cloak over him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With Amasa’s body out of the way, everyone went on with Joab to capture Sheba son of Bicri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, Sheba traveled through all the tribes of Israel and eventually came to the town of Abel-beth-maacah. All the members of his own clan, the Bicrites, assembled for battle and followed him into the town.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joab’s forces arrived, they attacked Abel-beth-maacah. They built a siege ramp against the town’s fortifications and began battering down the wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But a wise woman in the town called out to Joab, “Listen to me, Joab. Come over here so I can talk to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As he approached, the woman asked, “Are you Joab?”
“I am,” he replied.
So she said, “Listen carefully to your servant.”
“I’m listening,” he said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she continued, “There used to be a saying, ‘If you want to settle an argument, ask advice at the town of Abel.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am one who is peace loving and faithful in Israel. But you are destroying an important town in Israel. Why do you want to devour what belongs to the Lord?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Joab replied, “Believe me, I don’t want to devour or destroy your town!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That’s not my purpose. All I want is a man named Sheba son of Bicri from the hill country of Ephraim, who has revolted against King David. If you hand over this one man to me, I will leave the town in peace.”
“All right,” the woman replied, “we will throw his head over the wall to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the woman went to all the people with her wise advice, and they cut off Sheba’s head and threw it out to Joab. So he blew the ram’s horn and called his troops back from the attack. They all returned to their homes, and Joab returned to the king at Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Joab was the commander of the army of Israel. Benaiah son of Jehoiada was captain of the king’s bodyguard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adoniram was in charge of forced labor. Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was the royal historian.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sheva was the court secretary. Zadok and Abiathar were the priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Ira, a descendant of Jair, was David’s personal priest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was a famine during David’s reign that lasted for three years, so David asked the Lord about it. And the Lord said, “The famine has come because Saul and his family are guilty of murdering the Gibeonites.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king summoned the Gibeonites. They were not part of Israel but were all that was left of the nation of the Amorites. The people of Israel had sworn not to kill them, but Saul, in his zeal for Israel and Judah, had tried to wipe them out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David asked them, “What can I do for you? How can I make amends so that you will bless the Lord’s people again?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Well, money can’t settle this matter between us and the family of Saul,” the Gibeonites replied. “Neither can we demand the life of anyone in Israel.”
“What can I do then?” David asked. “Just tell me and I will do it for you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they replied, “It was Saul who planned to destroy us, to keep us from having any place at all in the territory of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So let seven of Saul’s sons be handed over to us, and we will execute them before the Lord at Gibeon, on the mountain of the Lord.”
“All right,” the king said, “I will do it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king spared Jonathan’s son Mephibosheth, who was Saul’s grandson, because of the oath David and Jonathan had sworn before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he gave them Saul’s two sons Armoni and Mephibosheth, whose mother was Rizpah daughter of Aiah. He also gave them the five sons of Saul’s daughter Merab, the wife of Adriel son of Barzillai from Meholah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of Gibeon executed them on the mountain before the Lord. So all seven of them died together at the beginning of the barley harvest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Rizpah daughter of Aiah, the mother of two of the men, spread burlap on a rock and stayed there the entire harvest season. She prevented the scavenger birds from tearing at their bodies during the day and stopped wild animals from eating them at night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David learned what Rizpah, Saul’s concubine, had done,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he went to the people of Jabesh-gilead and retrieved the bones of Saul and his son Jonathan. (When the Philistines had killed Saul and Jonathan on Mount Gilboa, the people of Jabesh-gilead stole their bodies from the public square of Beth-shan, where the Philistines had hung them.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David obtained the bones of Saul and Jonathan, as well as the bones of the men the Gibeonites had executed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king ordered that they bury the bones in the tomb of Kish, Saul’s father, at the town of Zela in the land of Benjamin. After that, God ended the famine in the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once again the Philistines were at war with Israel. And when David and his men were in the thick of battle, David became weak and exhausted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishbi-benob was a descendant of the giants; his bronze spearhead weighed more than seven pounds, and he was armed with a new sword. He had cornered David and was about to kill him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Abishai son of Zeruiah came to David’s rescue and killed the Philistine. Then David’s men declared, “You are not going out to battle with us again! Why risk snuffing out the light of Israel?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, there was another battle against the Philistines at Gob. As they fought, Sibbecai from Hushah killed Saph, another descendant of the giants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During another battle at Gob, Elhanan son of Jair from Bethlehem killed the brother of Goliath of Gath. The handle of his spear was as thick as a weaver’s beam!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In another battle with the Philistines at Gath, they encountered a huge man with six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot, twenty-four in all, who was also a descendant of the giants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when he defied and taunted Israel, he was killed by Jonathan, the son of David’s brother Shimea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These four Philistines were descendants of the giants of Gath, but David and his warriors killed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David sang this song to the Lord on the day the Lord rescued him from all his enemies and from Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He sang:
“The Lord is my rock, my fortress, and my savior;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
my God is my rock, in whom I find protection.
He is my shield, the power that saves me,
    and my place of safety.
He is my refuge, my savior,
    the one who saves me from violence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I called on the Lord, who is worthy of praise,
    and he saved me from my enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The waves of death overwhelmed me;
    floods of destruction swept over me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The grave wrapped its ropes around me;
    death laid a trap in my path.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
He opened the heavens and came down;
    dark storm clouds were beneath his feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Mounted on a mighty angelic being, he flew,
    soaring on the wings of the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He shrouded himself in darkness,
    veiling his approach with dense rain clouds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A great brightness shone around him,
    and burning coals blazed forth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord thundered from heaven;
    the voice of the Most High resounded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He shot arrows and scattered his enemies;
    his lightning flashed, and they were confused.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then at the command of the Lord,
    at the blast of his breath,
the bottom of the sea could be seen,
    and the foundations of the earth were laid bare.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“He reached down from heaven and rescued me;
    he drew me out of deep waters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He rescued me from my powerful enemies,
    from those who hated me and were too strong for me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They attacked me at a moment when I was in distress,
    but the Lord supported me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He led me to a place of safety;
    he rescued me because he delights in me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord rewarded me for doing right;
    he restored me because of my innocence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For I have kept the ways of the Lord;
    I have not turned from my God to follow evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have followed all his regulations;
    I have never abandoned his decrees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I am blameless before God;
    I have kept myself from sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord rewarded me for doing right.
    He has seen my innocence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“To the faithful you show yourself faithful;
    to those with integrity you show integrity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
To the pure you show yourself pure,
    but to the crooked you show yourself shrewd.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You rescue the humble,
    but your eyes watch the proud and humiliate them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
O Lord, you are my lamp.
    The Lord lights up my darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In your strength I can crush an army;
    with my God I can scale any wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“God’s way is perfect.
    All the Lord’s promises prove true.
    He is a shield for all who look to him for protection.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For who is God except the Lord?
    Who but our God is a solid rock?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God is my strong fortress,
    and he makes my way perfect.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He makes me as surefooted as a deer,
    enabling me to stand on mountain heights.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He trains my hands for battle;
    he strengthens my arm to draw a bronze bow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have given me your shield of victory;
    your help has made me great.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have made a wide path for my feet
    to keep them from slipping.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I chased my enemies and destroyed them;
    I did not stop until they were conquered.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
You have armed me with strength for the battle;
    you have subdued my enemies under my feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You placed my foot on their necks.
    I have destroyed all who hated me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They looked for help, but no one came to their rescue.
    They even cried to the Lord, but he refused to answer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I ground them as fine as the dust of the earth;
    I trampled them in the gutter like dirt.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Foreign nations cringe before me;
    as soon as they hear of me, they submit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They all lose their courage
    and come trembling from their strongholds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The Lord lives! Praise to my Rock!
    May God, the Rock of my salvation, be exalted!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He is the God who pays back those who harm me;
    he brings down the nations under me
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
For this, O Lord, I will praise you among the nations;
    I will sing praises to your name.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
These are the last words of David:
“David, the son of Jesse, speaks—
    David, the man who was raised up so high,
David, the man anointed by the God of Jacob,
    David, the sweet psalmist of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The Spirit of the Lord speaks through me;
    his words are upon my tongue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The God of Israel spoke.
    The Rock of Israel said to me:
‘The one who rules righteously,
    who rules in the fear of God,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
is like the light of morning at sunrise,
    like a morning without clouds,
like the gleaming of the sun
    on new grass after rain.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Is it not my family God has chosen?
    Yes, he has made an everlasting covenant with me.
His agreement is arranged and guaranteed in every detail.
    He will ensure my safety and success.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But the godless are like thorns to be thrown away,
    for they tear the hand that touches them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
One must use iron tools to chop them down;
    they will be totally consumed by fire.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the names of David’s mightiest warriors. The first was Jashobeam the Hacmonite, who was leader of the Three—the three mightiest warriors among David’s men. He once used his spear to kill 800 enemy warriors in a single battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next in rank among the Three was Eleazar son of Dodai, a descendant of Ahoah. Once Eleazar and David stood together against the Philistines when the entire Israelite army had fled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He killed Philistines until his hand was too tired to lift his sword, and the Lord gave him a great victory that day. The rest of the army did not return until it was time to collect the plunder!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next in rank was Shammah son of Agee from Harar. One time the Philistines gathered at Lehi and attacked the Israelites in a field full of lentils. The Israelite army fled,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but Shammah held his ground in the middle of the field and beat back the Philistines. So the Lord brought about a great victory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once during the harvest, when David was at the cave of Adullam, the Philistine army was camped in the valley of Rephaim. The Three (who were among the Thirty—an elite group among David’s fighting men) went down to meet him there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was staying in the stronghold at the time, and a Philistine detachment had occupied the town of Bethlehem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David remarked longingly to his men, “Oh, how I would love some of that good water from the well by the gate in Bethlehem.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Three broke through the Philistine lines, drew some water from the well by the gate in Bethlehem, and brought it back to David. But he refused to drink it. Instead, he poured it out as an offering to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The Lord forbid that I should drink this!” he exclaimed. “This water is as precious as the blood of these men who risked their lives to bring it to me.” So David did not drink it. These are examples of the exploits of the Three.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abishai son of Zeruiah, the brother of Joab, was the leader of the Thirty. He once used his spear to kill 300 enemy warriors in a single battle. It was by such feats that he became as famous as the Three.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abishai was the most famous of the Thirty and was their commander, though he was not one of the Three.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was also Benaiah son of Jehoiada, a valiant warrior from Kabzeel. He did many heroic deeds, which included killing two champions of Moab. Another time, on a snowy day, he chased a lion down into a pit and killed it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once, armed only with a club, he killed an imposing Egyptian warrior who was armed with a spear. Benaiah wrenched the spear from the Egyptian’s hand and killed him with it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Deeds like these made Benaiah as famous as the Three mightiest warriors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was more honored than the other members of the Thirty, though he was not one of the Three. And David made him captain of his bodyguard.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

Shammah from Harod;
Elika from Harod;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Helez from Pelon;
Ira son of Ikkesh from Tekoa;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Abiezer from Anathoth;
Sibbecai from Hushah;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Zalmon from Ahoah;
Maharai from Netophah;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Heled son of Baanah from Netophah;
Ithai son of Ribai from Gibeah (in the land of Benjamin);
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Benaiah from Pirathon;
Hurai from Nahale-gaash;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Abi-albon from Arabah;
Azmaveth from Bahurim;
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
son of Shagee from Harar;
Ahiam son of Sharar from Harar;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Eliphelet son of Ahasbai from Maacah;
Eliam son of Ahithophel from Giloh;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Hezro from Carmel;
Paarai from Arba;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Igal son of Nathan from Zobah;
Bani from Gad;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Zelek from Ammon;
Naharai from Beeroth, the armor bearer of Joab son of Zeruiah;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ira from Jattir;
Gareb from Jattir;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Uriah the Hittite.
There were thirty-seven in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once again the anger of the Lord burned against Israel, and he caused David to harm them by taking a census. “Go and count the people of Israel and Judah,” the Lord told him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king said to Joab and the commanders of the army, “Take a census of all the tribes of Israel—from Dan in the north to Beersheba in the south—so I may know how many people there are.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Joab replied to the king, “May the Lord your God let you live to see a hundred times as many people as there are now! But why, my lord the king, do you want to do this?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king insisted that they take the census, so Joab and the commanders of the army went out to count the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: First they crossed the Jordan and camped at Aroer, south of the town in the valley, in the direction of Gad. Then they went on to Jazer,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then to Gilead in the land of Tahtim-hodshi and to Dan-jaan and around to Sidon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they came to the fortress of Tyre, and all the towns of the Hivites and Canaanites. Finally, they went south to Judah as far as Beersheba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Having gone through the entire land for nine months and twenty days, they returned to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab reported the number of people to the king. There were 800,000 capable warriors in Israel who could handle a sword, and 500,000 in Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But after he had taken the census, David’s conscience began to bother him. And he said to the Lord, “I have sinned greatly by taking this census. Please forgive my guilt, Lord, for doing this foolish thing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next morning the word of the Lord came to the prophet Gad, who was David’s seer. This was the message:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go and say to David, ‘This is what the Lord says: I will give you three choices. Choose one of these punishments, and I will inflict it on you.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Gad came to David and asked him, “Will you choose three years of famine throughout your land, three months of fleeing from your enemies, or three days of severe plague throughout your land? Think this over and decide what answer I should give the Lord who sent me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I’m in a desperate situation!” David replied to Gad. “But let us fall into the hands of the Lord, for his mercy is great. Do not let me fall into human hands.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord sent a plague upon Israel that morning, and it lasted for three days. A total of 70,000 people died throughout the nation, from Dan in the north to Beersheba in the south.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But as the angel was preparing to destroy Jerusalem, the Lord relented and said to the death angel, “Stop! That is enough!” At that moment the angel of the Lord was by the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David saw the angel, he said to the Lord, “I am the one who has sinned and done wrong! But these people are as innocent as sheep—what have they done? Let your anger fall against me and my family.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That day Gad came to David and said to him, “Go up and build an altar to the Lord on the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David went up to do what the Lord had commanded him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Araunah saw the king and his men coming toward him, he came and bowed before the king with his face to the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Why have you come, my lord the king?” Araunah asked.
David replied, “I have come to buy your threshing floor and to build an altar to the Lord there, so that he will stop the plague.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Take it, my lord the king, and use it as you wish,” Araunah said to David. “Here are oxen for the burnt offering, and you can use the threshing boards and ox yokes for wood to build a fire on the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will give it all to you, Your Majesty, and may the Lord your God accept your sacrifice.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king replied to Araunah, “No, I insist on buying it, for I will not present burnt offerings to the Lord my God that have cost me nothing.” So David paid him fifty pieces of silver for the threshing floor and the oxen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David built an altar there to the Lord and sacrificed burnt offerings and peace offerings. And the Lord answered his prayer for the land, and the plague on Israel was stopped.
verses.speaker: Narrator
